sen.j: 小唄（こうた）には、もともと端唄から派生した俗謡である。
sen.e: "Kouta" is a popular song accompanied with shamisen, which was originally derived from "hauta" (a Japanese short ballad accompanied with shamisen).

sen.j: 一般には江戸小唄とされる端唄の略称。
sen.e: Generally, kouta is used as the abbreviation of "Edo kouta" (hauta performed and enjoyed in Edo).

sen.j: ほかに現代小唄・清元小唄・常磐津小唄・義太夫小唄（豊本節）・新内小唄などがある。
sen.e: In addition to Edo kouta, there exist various kouta, such as "gendai kouta" (modern kouta), "kiyomoto kouta," "tokiwazu kouta," "gidayu kouta" (also called "toyomoto-bushi"), and "shinnai kouta" - kiyomoto, tokiwazu, gidayu and shinnai are originally the names of "katarimono" (narrative shamisen music), but here, these are arranged as "utaimono" (lyrical shamisen music).
sen.cmt: ・4行目のダッシュの後に訳者が補っている解説の内容は、「清元・常磐津・義太夫・新内は、もともとは『語り物』の名前であるが、ここでは『謡物（うたいもの）』として編曲されている」です。（参照：[http://kouta-renmei.org/english.html])

sen.e: Kouta was mainly performed in a Japanese-style drawing room of the size of four and a half "tatami" (a Japanese floor mat), so the player naturally began to pluck with its fingers, instead of the plectrum that made the sound too big for the room.
